source.description:
Prepare the following solutions for TNA extraction
Use clean and preferably baked glassware (make sure all non-glass components can withstand the high temperatures).

One of the following phosphate buffers:

Phosphate buffer (
,
)
Dissolve the salts in RNase-free water and fill up to 500 ml. Autoclave.

Phosphate buffer (
,
)
Dissolve the salts in RNase-free water and fill up to 500 ml. Autoclave.

Phosphate buffer + AlNH4 (120 mM PB pH 8.0 + 0.1M AlNH4(SO4)2•12H2O)


Dissolve in PB. Autoclave.

Store at

Either TNC or TNS
TNC
Dissolve the salts in RNase-free water and fill up to 200 ml. Autoclave.

TNS
Dissolve the salts in RNase-free water and fill up to 200 ml. Autoclave.

Store at

PEG precipitation solution (30%)
Add ingredients to a graduated Duran bottle. Add water to fill up to 200 ml, shake vigorously by hand, autoclave and mix well while hot (solution turns milky when hot, but then turns clear when cooled to room temperature).
Store at

Molecular-grade ethanol solution (75%)


Store at

Low-EDTA TE buffer
Prepare in a laminar-flow hood (to protect stocks), filter sterilise (0.2 µm) and autoclave.
Store at

Weigh
(0.2-0.7 g) into a Lysing Matrix E tube, or a 2-ml screw-cap tube filled with 0.7 g (one full PCR tube) of 0.1 mm glass beads and place the tube
.

Add
of either PB pH 8.0, PB pH 5.8 or PB+Al,
of TNC or TNS and
of TE-saturated phenol (if using PB pH 8.0) or water-saturated phenol (if using PB pH 5.8). Alternatively, add
of PB,
of TNC or TNS, if not using phenol (see
Guidelines and Warnings
on which combination of solutions to choose.)

Immediately place the tube in a sample homogeniser and process for
at 6.5 m s-1. We recommend using the FastPrep-24™ sample homogenizer with the CoolPrep™ adapter for 24 x 2 ml
. If using the CoolPrep™ adapter make sure all slots are filled with either sample or empty tubes.

source.name: FastPrep-24™ 5G bead beating grinder and lysis system
CoolPrep™ adapter for 24 x 2 mL tube holder on FastPrep-24

source.description:
Chill
for
(not necessary if using the CoolPrep™ adapter).

Centrifuge at
(centrifugation at RT is also possible).
Transfer the entire liquid (aqueous and organic phases) to a fresh 2 ml tube by decanting or pipetting. tubes.

source.body: Your supernatant has two phases. An aqueous upper phase that should be transparent/translucent and a phenol phase that should be opaque. Make sure to pour both into the fresh 2 ml tube.

source.description: Repeat Steps 3-7 two more times using the same Lysing Matrix E tube. Be careful not to overfill the tube as this might cause phenol leakage during the sample homogenising process. If there is not enough space in the tube for all the reagents, decrease the phenol volume (down to 200 μl). For the second homogenising repetition use a fresh 2 ml tube to collect the supernatant in Step 7, while for the third repetition divide the supernatant between the two tubes from the previous repetitions to achieve equal volumes.

Add
(or 1 volume) to each of the tubes containing the supernatant, to a maximum of 2 ml total volume in each tube.

Mix the two phases , by hand or using a vortex. Centrifuge
.

Using a 1-ml pipette tip, carefully transfer the aqueous phase (the upper phase) from each tube to two fresh 2 ml tubes.
Be careful not to touch or pipette the interphase or the organic phase (the lower phase)

source.body: If, by mistake, some of the interphase or organic phase were pipetted, simply return the liquid to the original tube and centrifuge it again.

source.description:
Add
(or 1 volume) to each tube.

Mix the phases vigorously by hand or using a vortex. Centrifuge
.
Carefully transfer the supernatant from each tube to a fresh 2 ml low-binding microcentrifuge tubes. At this point, you should have two low-binding tubes per sample.

source.body: If, by mistake, some of the interphase or organic phase were pipetted, simply return the liquid to the original tube and centrifuge it again.

source.description:
Add to each tube
and
(or twice the extract’s volume).

Centrifuge
.

Decant the supernatant, briefly centrifuge or spin-down again to collect the drops and using a pipette remove as much as possible from the remaining precipitation solution. Be careful not to disturb the pellet.

Add
, invert the tube several times. Centrifuge at
.
Remove the supernatant using a pipette, shortly centrifuge again to collect the drops and using a pipette remove as much as possible from the remaining ethanol. Be careful not to disturb the pellet.

Leave the tubes open at
for approximately
(preferably under a flame, inside a laminar-flow hood, or inverted on a piece of kitchen paper, to prevent contamination) to evaporate the remaining ethanol. Alternatively, the pellets can be dried under a filtered stream of N2, or in a speed-vac.

source.body: The pellets might not be completely dry at this point, but the remaining liquid should be pure water.

source.description:
Resuspend each pellet in
to
and combine both subsamples into one of the non-stick tubes.

Remove co-extracted humic substances using OneStep™ PCR Inhibitor Removal Kit

This step is optional but very recommended.
Resuspend the resin in the column by brief vortexing (if the column is dry, add 100 μl of RNAse-free water prior to vortexing.)
Loosen the cap by a quarter twist, place the column in a collection tube and centrifuge
Place the column in a fresh 1.5 ml tube, pipette the entire TNA extract (up to 200 μl) on top of the resin.

source.body: Be careful not to disturb the resin with the tip

source.description: Centrifuge
Discard the column and retain the extract in the tube.

Optional: load
to
of the total NA extract on an agarose gel to evaluate its quantity and quality using electrophoresis.

Quantify total NA extract using RiboGreen™ and PicoGreen™ (see
Guidelines and Warnings
) or only DNA using PicoGreen™.

This protocol is a simplified and condensed version of the full protocol from the manufacturer. The procedure described here is for 96 reactions. If samples are run in duplicates, then this should allow quantifying 40 samples.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"length":1,"offset":105,"style":"sup"}],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":49,"offset":87},{"key":1,"length":13,"offset":198}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[{"type":"link","data":{"guid":"5DCB0B9074B211EA8D5EB7C0B3B526E9","url":"https:\/\/www.thermofisher.com\/order\/catalog\/product\/P7589?ICID=search-p7589#\/P7589?ICID=search-p7589"}},{"type":"link","data":{"guid":"FBADF13D74B111EA914D0242AC110002","url":"https:\/\/www.thermofisher.com\/document-connect\/document-connect.html?url=https%3A%2F%2Fassets.thermofisher.com%2FTFS-Assets%2FLSG%2Fmanuals%2Fmp07581.pdf&title=UXVhbnQtaVQgUGljb0dyZWVuIGRzRE5BIFJlYWdlbnQgYW5kIEtpdHM="}}]}

to

to
for RNA purification.

source.description: {"blocks":[{"key":"6oiq","text":"The following protocol is intended as a downstream application for our Total Nucleic Acids Extraction from Soil protocol. This protocol describes how to purify RNA from a DNA and RNA extract using TURBO\u2122 DNase and GeneJET RNA Cleanup and Concentration Micro Kit. This protocol is a simplified and condensed version of the full protocols provided by the manufacturers.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"length":40,"offset":71},{"key":1,"length":12,"offset":197},{"key":2,"length":47,"offset":214}],"data":[]}],"entityMap":[{"type":"link","data":{"guid":"109429B08AC411EA975E971814C71417","url":"https:\/\/protocols.io\/view\/total-nucleic-acids-extraction-from-soil-yw9fxh6"}},{"type":"link","data":{"guid":"E68F85508AC411EA975E971814C71417","url":"https:\/\/www.thermofisher.com\/order\/catalog\/product\/AM2238?SID=srch-srp-AM2238#\/AM2238?SID=srch-srp-AM2238"}},{"type":"link","data":{"guid":"8F3687408AC411EA975E971814C71417","url":"https:\/\/www.thermofisher.com\/order\/catalog\/product\/K0841#\/legacy=www.thermoscientificbio.com"}}]}
If the removal of RNA is necessary, follow up with RNaseH treatment and purification using e.g. Genomic DNA Clean & Concentrator.

description: The following protocol is intended for the simultaneous extraction of DNA and RNA (total nucleic acids, or TNA) from various soil and sediment samples. The protocol was designed based on two protocols published by Henckel et al. (1999) and Griffiths et al. (2000), with several critical modifications. Recently, we have added the option to include an ammonium aluminium sulfate salt for soils with high humic content (Braid et al., 2003). The result is a highly flexible and streamlined protocol, which delivers high yields of nucleic acids with quality suitable for all downstream molecular applications from most types of soil and sediment samples. Please cite Angel et al. (2012).
